title: Bill Belichick finds buyer for his $3.9M Nantucket cottage — days after putting it on the market
description: Legendary New England Patriots head coach Bill Belichick has finally found a buyer for his sprawling beachfront Massachusetts $3.9 million cottage — five days after listing the charming dwelling.…
content:
Legendary New England Patriots head coach Bill Belichick has finally found a buyer for his sprawling beachfront Massachusetts $3.9 million cottage — five days after listing the charming dwelling.

The 73-year-old football legend — who has stirred up controversy due to his relationship with 24-year-old girlfriend Jordon Hudson — snapped up the stunning three-bedroom, two-bathroom abode in 2014 for $2.45 million.

Just a few days ago, Belichick decided to offload his Nantucket dwelling in preparation for his new role as the head football coach of the University of North Carolina after 24 seasons with the Patriots, during which the team garnered six Super Bowl wins.

Now, Realtor.com® can exclusively reveal that the football mogul has found a buyer, with the home officially being in the contingency phase, which means that Belichick has accepted an offer; however, the sale is contingent on certain conditions.

It is unclear how much the buyer offered Belichick, but the home was listed for $3.895 million.

According to the listing, which was held by Coldwell Banker, the property features a “vaulted living room with stone fireplace and views of the beach and conservation land. The cottage exudes old world charm with wooden walls, built-in bookshelves, a window with diamond mullions, and many nooks and crannies while still offering modern amenities for today’s living.”

Belichick — who boasts a net worth of $70 million — holds the keys to several properties in Massachusetts and is even building a new home just down the street from the abode he put on the market.

In 2006, Belichick reportedly snapped up his first Massachusetts home for a relatively modest $1.4 million.

The three-bedroom, three-bathroom home sprawls across 4,400 square feet and boasts a two-car garage.

According to the original listing, the property overlooks a third hole on a golf course and features two pools, a tennis court, a clubhouse, and a recreation center.

Inside, there is a media room, wine cellar, and wet bar.

Although he purchased the charming abode for $1.4 million, Realtor.com® now estimates Belichick’s property is worth $2.1 million.

In 2024, he forked over $4.8 million for a 2,854-square-foot Nantucket home.

The four-bedroom, four-bathroom property was built in 1983 and boasts an expansive living area, a sophisticated dining space, and an office space.

On the second floor, there is an en suite primary bedroom and two guest rooms with a shared bath.

The property was renovated in 2017 and features a basement with an additional bathroom and tub.

Belichick previously gushed about Nantucket while speaking to N Magazine in 2017, telling the outlet: “The island is spectacular. The people are great, fishing, bike paths, the lighthouses, the beach, the history — I mean it’s got it all.”

The legendary coach once held the keys to another Nantucket property, which he purchased for $4.6 million in 2006; however, property records indicate that the home went to his ex-wife, Debby Clarke, after they divorced that same year.

According to the documents, the former couple purchased the home together; however, it is now solely registered in her name.

The property boasts five bedrooms, four bathrooms, and several cozy fireplaces.

When he isn’t enjoying one of his many homes in Massachusetts, the NFL coach is laying low in his stunning Florida condo, which he purchased in 2009.

The four-bedroom, three-bathroom home sprawls across 4,085 square feet and boasts 20-foot ceilings and sweeping views of the deep sea.

Although he snapped up the property for $1.6 million, Realtor.com® now estimates it is worth $3.7 million.

The property is located right off of a golf course and boasts a wine cellar and an encircled patio.

Since bidding farewell to his long career with the Patriots in January, Belichick has been at the center of headlines due to his controversial romance with Hudson, a former cheerleader and beauty pageant contestant.

The couple, who began dating in 2023, have been thrown into the hot seat time and time again since going public with their age-gap relationship.

They previously had their romance thrown into the spotlight during the NFL Honors, when they were mercilessly roasted by rapper Snoop Dogg over their 48-year age gap.

Telling the crowd that he’s been “a football fan for a long time,” Snoop, 53, said that many things have changed since he first started watching games “back when the Cowboys was good” and “when the Chiefs was bad.”

“And I remember, what was it — Bill Belichick’s girlfriend wasn’t even born yet?” he joked, leaving Hudson open-mouthed in surprise, while her partner simply chuckled along with the rest of the audience.

The longtime coach’s dating life wasn’t even spared by two of his most successful players, Tom Brady and Rob Gronkowski, both of whom savaged him over it during Netflix’s “The Roast of Tom Brady.”

“Coach, you used to talk about Foxborough High School when we sucked,” Gronkowski said during the livestreamed special on May 5, 2024. “But now I know why you were so obsessed with Foxborough High School: You were scouting your new girlfriend.”

Brady then followed that up by mocking Belichick over Ring camera footage that caught him sneaking out of Hudson’s home shirtless, saying: “Everybody asks me which ring is my favorite, I used to say ‘the next one.’

“But now that I am retired, my favorite Ring is the camera that caught Coach Belichick slinking out of that poor girl’s house a few months ago. Hey, you still got it. Respect, baby.”

The home in question was located in Massachusetts home where former cheerleader Hudson was living at the time — having attended Bridgewater State University.

In addition to boasting an impressive career as a cheerleader, Hudson also holds an $8 million property portfolio, forging the path for her to become a real estate mogul.

She began snapping up a host of multifamily homes in the greater Boston area in December 2023, property records reveal, just a few months after she was first seen spending time with Belichick, 73, although they are reported to have met around 18 months earlier.

According to mortgage documents seen by Realtor.com®, Hudson purchased three multi-family dwellings at the end of 2023, all of which were purchased through separate LLCs, but with the former cheerleader’s name listed as the “borrower” for each.

As first reported by DailyMail.com, Hudson took out a $1.2 million mortgage on the first dwelling — a $2.2 million Dorchester townhouse that has been converted into three separate apartments — on Dec. 1, 2023, with a listing on Realtor.com revealing that one of the units in the property is currently available to rent for $5,000 a month.

The listing suggests that Hudson has spent time renovating the property since she purchased it, calling attention to the “beautiful” updates that have been made to the four-bedroom unit.

On the same day that she completed mortgage paperwork on the first apartment building, Hudson also took out a $1.2 million mortgage on another nearby townhouse conversion, which was purchased for $2.3 million.

However, records indicate that the property was purchased a few months earlier, in June 2023, just over one month after it was listed.

Much like her first townhouse, the second property has been split into three apartments, all of which feature four bedrooms and two bathrooms, with the original listing revealing that the building had been “renovated to the studs” prior to being put on the market.

Located in Dorchester’s “vibrant Polish Triangle neighborhood,” the apartments all come complete with private outdoor space, as well as high ceilings and ample natural light, per the online description.

The third property in Hudson’s booming real estate collection is in Boston, in the city’s Roxbury Crossing neighborhood.

Hudson paid $3 million for that multifamily dwelling, which she purchased on Dec. 15, 2023, just two weeks after buying the properties in Dorchester.

In its listing, the property was described as a “one-of-a-kind three-family home” that features a total of 15 bedrooms and 8.5 bathrooms spread across three separate units.

When it was listed, the description noted that all three of the units were leased until August 2024, “generating a rental income of $17,675 a month.”

On all of the mortgage documents for those properties, Hudson listed a fourth dwelling — this time a single-family home — as her residence, a quaint two-bedroom cottage in Harwich, MA, which she purchased for $610,000 in October 2023.

Located on the side of a pond, the property features two bathrooms and a “small but workable” kitchen, per the listing.
summary: Legendary New England Patriots head coach Bill Belichick has found a buyer for his beachfront Massachusetts $3.9 million cottage, five days after he put it on the market. The three-bedroom, two-bathroom abode was purchased in 2014 for $2.45 million. This follows Belichick's decision to sell his Nantucket home in preparation for his new role as head football coach of the University of North Carolina after 24 seasons with the Patriots. The sale is contingent on certain conditions. Despite his net worth of $70 million, Belichick holds the keys to several properties in Massachusetts and is even building a new home just down the street from the abode he put on.
shortSummary: Bill Belichick has found a buyer for his Nantucket cottage, which he purchased for $2.4 million in 2014, pending certain conditions.

Bill Belichick's provocative girlfriend Jordon Hudson, 24, has quietly amassed a $9 MILLION real estate empire since hooking up with the 73-year-old sports legend
Bill Belichick's 49-years-younger girlfriend made headlines this week when she muscled in on his CBS interview.
But awkward headlines aren't the only thing Jordon Hudson, 24, has been racking up. The former cheerleader has quietly amassed a real estate portfolio worth $9.1 million since the controversial couple began dating, the Daily Mail can reveal.
Hudson has snapped up at least four properties, including one worth $3million, which were all purchased after she met the former New England Patriots coach, 73, in 2021.
Even more impressively, public records reveal Belichick's girlfriend has already paid off the mortgages on all of these homes.
Since she began dating the eight-time Super Bowl winner, Hudson has also registered 18 companies - several with names that suggest she has some control over his affairs.
Hudson, the daughter of a fisherman from Maine, has also managed to secure the services of a high-end wealth manager whose firm requires its clients to have at least $2million in assets.
Jordon Hudson has quietly built a $9.1 million real estate empire since she began dating NFL legend Bill Belichick, the Daily Mail can reveal
Public records show the former college cheerleader, 24, has snapped up at least four properties since she linked up with the NFL Hall of Famer in 2021
Neither Belichick nor Hudson have responded to the Daily Mail's request for comment.
The legendary NFL coach, who is said to be worth around $70million, refers to Hudson as his 'idea mill and creative muse' in his forthcoming memoir which is out in May.
Hudson's role in Belichick's life became a topic of national conversation after she interrupted his CBS interview about his book on Sunday to shut down questions about how they met.
'We're not talking about this', she said, even though the reported story of the pair meeting on a plane appears to be innocuous.
Hudson, who is competing in the Miss Maine USA beauty pageant in May, is said to have stormed out of the interview for 30 minutes and delayed the filming.
Friends of Belichick have reportedly raised concerns that the relationship is a 'runaway train' and claim Hudson 'saw an opening and took it' with him.
They are said to be staging an intervention but 'very gently because they know how deep in he is', the New York Post claimed.
A $3million, three-bedroom home in the Roxbury Crossing area of Boston was bought by Hudson in December 2023
Hudson took out a $1.1million mortgage on the property
A large townhouse which is divided up into three large apartments in Dorchester, Massachusetts, was bought by Hudson on December 1, 2023
Hudson got a $1.1million mortgage on the $2.2million home. One four-bedroom apartment in the building is currently on the market for rent for $4,900 a month
The full extent of Hudson's assets will likely raise further questions about her relationship with Belichick, who is infamous for being a micromanager.
Records obtained by the Daily Mail show three of Hudson's properties were bought in a cluster within three days of each other in December 2023, when Belichick was still in charge of the New England Patriots, during his 24th and final season.
Suffolk County deed records show that Hudson bought two large townhouses in Dorchester, Massachusetts on December 1, 2023 - one worth $2.2m and the other $2.3m. Hudson got a $1.1m mortgage on both properties, which are each divided into three large apartments.
One four-bedroom apartment in the first building is currently available for rent at $4,900 a month.
A second property, also a large townhouse in Dorchester, worth $2.3million was bought on the same day
Records show she got another substantial mortgage of $1.1million on the home, which is also divided up into three apartments
The fourth property, in Harwich, Massachusetts, is a two-bedroom, 1,200 sq ft cottage
The property was purchased on October 18, 2023 for $610,000, property records show, with a mortgage of $488,000.
Then on December 8, 2023, Hudson took out a mortgage on her most expensive property yet: a $3million, three-bedroom family home in the Roxbury Crossing area of Boston.
Yet again, she got a $1.1million mortgage on the property.
A fourth property - bought nearly two months before the other three houses - is a two-bedroom, 1,200 sq ft cottage located in Harwich, Massachusetts. It was purchased on October 18, 2023 for $610,000 and property records show it had a mortgage of $488,000.
Hudson used a trust called the TCE Trust, created on June 12, 2023, to help with the transaction.
But the most intriguing twist was yet to come: according to Massachusetts property records, all four mortgages were paid off within a week of each other in late January this year.
Hudson's role in Belichick's life became a topic of national conversation this week when she interrupted his CBS interview (pictured) about his book to shut down questions about how they met
The stony-faced 24-year-old was seen in the background before awkwardly muscling into boyfriend Bill Belichick's CBS interview
The 18 companies set up by Hudson are mostly in the state of Massachusetts.
Some were set up to help her buy properties, such as TCE Cottage LLC, but others suggest she could be more involved in running Belichick's life.
Among them is Trouble Club Enterprises LLC, set up on January 20 this year.
On her LinkedIn page, Hudson says she is chief executive and founder of a company of the same name.
The LinkedIn page also states that, as of August last year, Hudson has been chief operating officer of 'Belichick Productions'.
A company by that name was set up in New Jersey on April 17 this year but it is unclear if it is related to Hudson.
Other companies set up by Hudson include 'All BB Team LLC', an apparent reference to Belichick, 'Chapel Bill LLC' and 'Coach Show LLC'. It is not clear how much she is managing Belichick's rights and image.
Hudson, a trained cosmetologist, has also set up 'Roosevelt Glam LLC' named after one of her middle names.
There are numerous versions of TCE such as 'TCE Creative Consulting LLC' and 'TCE Rights Management'. There is even a company called 'TEC Tech Support LLC' suggesting she is involved in IT too.
On her LinkedIn page, Hudson, a philosophy graduate from Bridgewater State University who only graduated in 2022, states her skills include real estate development, contract management, strategic partnerships, mergers and acquisitions and leadership development.
Belichick's girlfriend Hudson shared an email from the coach to Instagram on Tuesday
Hudson's interruption of Belichick's interview sparked fears for the 73-year-old coach amid his relationship with the former cheerleader
The couple were photographed together after enjoying a double date night with friends at the Boarding House, a swanky private members club in Nantucket, last June
Now at college level with North Carolina, striking footage recently emerged of Hudson by Belichick's side as he coached the team at a spring camp
The names that appear on the property and company documents are Massachusetts real-estate lawyer David Jensen and Joshua Christian, an advisor with Cerity Partners, a high-end wealth management company based in Boston.
On Cerity's website, the company says that its clients have to have a minimum of $2million in assets and pay an annual fee of $20,000 to use its services.
The Daily Mail has contacted Cerity and Jensen for comment.
Previous reports have raised questions about how much Hudson is in charge of Belichick's life. She recently moved with him to Chapel Hill, where the head coach is preparing for his first season coaching college ball for the University of North Carolina.
At the dinner table, the couple were seen locked in conversation and gazing at each other lovingly
Last month it emerged that Belichick wanted Hudson copied in on all emails between him and Robbi Pickeral Evans, the school's Senior Associate Athletic Director for External Affairs and Strategic Communications.
In her email signature, Hudson refers to herself as Chief Operating Officer of Belichick Productions.
She has also been involved in negotiations with the NFL about a documentary covering Belichick and UNC, it has been reported.
One of Belichick's friends told the New York Post: 'This guy is known as being such a strong voice and in many ways autocratic - and here he is becoming mush in her hands and letting her direct everything.
'She is so much younger, so inexperienced and so lacking in perspective and professionalism'.

Bill Belichick lists Nantucket beachfront cottage for $3.9M — one week before starting as head coach at UNC
Iconic New England Patriots head coach Bill Belichick has put his beachfront Massachusetts cottage on the market for $3.9 million—just one week before moving onto a new coaching chapter at the University of North Carolina.
The 73-year-old football legend—who has stirred up controversy due to his relationship with 24-year-old girlfriend Jordan Hudson—snapped up the stunning three-bedroom, two-bathroom abode in 2014 for $2.45 million.
Now, Belichick has decided to offload his Nantucket dwelling as he prepares to enter a new chapter as the head football coach of the University of North Carolina after 24 seasons with the Patriots, during which the team garnered six Super Bowl wins.
According to the listing, which is held by Coldwell Banker, the property features a “vaulted living room with stone fireplace and views of the beach and conservation land. The cottage exudes old world charm with wooden walls, built-in bookshelves, a window with diamond mullions, and many nooks and crannies while still offering modern amenities for today’s living.”
Belichick—who boasts a net worth of $70 million—holds the keys to several properties in Massachusetts and is even building a new home just down the street from the abode he put on the market.
In 2006, Belichick reportedly snapped up his first Massachusetts home for a relatively modest $1.4 million.
The three-bedroom, three-bathroom home sprawls across 4,400 square feet and boasts a two-car garage.
According to the original listing, the property overlooks a third hole on a golf course and features two pools, a tennis court, a clubhouse, and a recreation center.
Inside, there is a media room, wine cellar, and wet bar.
Although he purchased the charming abode for $1.4 million, Realtor.com® now estimates Belichick’s property is worth $2.1 million.
In 2024, he forked over $4.8 million for a 2,854-square-foot Nantucket home.
The four-bedroom, four-bathroom property was built in 1983 and boasts an expansive living area, a sophisticated dining space, and an office space.
On the second floor, there is an en suite primary bedroom and two guest rooms with a shared bath.
The property was renovated in 2017 and features a basement with an additional bathroom and tub.
Belichick previously gushed about Nantucket while speaking to N Magazine in 2017, telling the outlet: “The island is spectacular. The people are great, fishing, bike paths, the lighthouses, the beach, the history—I mean it’s got it all.”
The legendary coach once held the keys to another Nantucket property, which he purchased for $4.6 million in 2006; however, property records indicate that the home went to his ex-wife, Debby Clarke, after they divorced that same year.
According to the documents, the former couple purchased the home together; however, it is now solely registered in her name.
The property boasts five bedrooms, four bathrooms, and several cozy fireplaces.
When he isn’t enjoying one of his many homes in Massachusetts, the NFL coach is laying low in his stunning Florida condo, which he purchased in 2009.
The four-bedroom, three-bathroom home sprawls across 4,085 square feet and boasts 20-foot ceilings and sweeping views of the deep sea.
Although he snapped up the property for $1.6 million, Realtor.com® now estimates it is worth $3.7 million.
The property is located right off of a golf course and boasts a wine cellar and an encircled patio.
Since bidding farewell to his long career with the Patriots in January, Belichick has been at the center of headlines due to his controversial romance with Hudson, a former cheerleader and beauty pageant contestant.
The couple, who began dating in 2023, have been thrown into the hot seat time and time again since going public with their age-gap relationship.
They previously had their romance thrown into the spotlight during the NFL Honors, when they were mercilessly roasted by rapper Snoop Dogg over their 48-year age gap.
Telling the crowd that he’s been “a football fan for a long time,” Snoop, 53, said that many things have changed since he first started watching games “back when the Cowboys was good” and “when the Chiefs was bad.”
“And I remember, what was it—Bill Belichick’s girlfriend wasn’t even born yet?” he joked, leaving Hudson open-mouthed in surprise, while her partner simply chuckled along with the rest of the audience.
The longtime coach’s dating life wasn’t even spared by two of his most successful players, Tom Brady and Rob Gronkowski, both of whom savaged him over it during Netflix’s “The Roast of Tom Brady.”
“Coach, you used to talk about Foxborough High School when we sucked,” Gronkowski said during the livestreamed special on May 5, 2024.
“But now I know why you were so obsessed with Foxborough High School: You were scouting your new girlfriend.”
Brady then followed that up by mocking Belichick over Ring camera footage that caught him sneaking out of Hudson’s home shirtless, saying: “Everybody asks me which ring is my favorite, I used to say ‘the next one.’
“But now that I am retired, my favorite Ring is the camera that caught Coach Belichick slinking out of that poor girl’s house a few months ago. Hey, you still got it. Respect, baby.”
The home in question was located in Massachusetts home where former cheerleader Hudson was living at the time—having attended Bridgewater State University.
In addition to boasting an impressive career as a cheerleader, Hudson also holds an $8 million property portfolio, forging the path for her to become a real estate mogul.
She began snapping up a host of multifamily homes in the greater Boston area in December 2023, property records reveal, just a few months after she was first seen spending time with Belichick, 73, although they are reported to have met around 18 months earlier.
According to mortgage documents seen by Realtor.com®, Hudson purchased three multi-family dwellings at the end of 2023, all of which were purchased through separate LLCs, but with the former cheerleader’s name listed as the “borrower” for each.
As first reported by DailyMail.com, Hudson took out a $1.2 million mortgage on the first dwelling—a $2.2 million Dorchester townhouse that has been converted into three separate apartments—on Dec. 1, 2023, with a listing on Realtor.com revealing that one of the units in the property is currently available to rent for $5,000 a month.
The listing suggests that Hudson has spent time renovating the property since she purchased it, calling attention to the “beautiful” updates that have been made to the four-bedroom unit.
On the same day that she completed mortgage paperwork on the first apartment building, Hudson also took out a $1.2 million mortgage on another nearby townhouse conversion, which was purchased for $2.3 million.
However, records indicate that the property was purchased a few months earlier, in June 2023, just over one month after it was listed.
Much like her first townhouse, the second property has been split into three apartments, all of which feature four bedrooms and two bathrooms, with the original listing revealing that the building had been “renovated to the studs” prior to being put on the market.
Located in Dorchester’s “vibrant Polish Triangle neighborhood,” the apartments all come complete with private outdoor space, as well as high ceilings and ample natural light, per the online description.
The third property in Hudson’s booming real estate collection is in Boston, in the city’s Roxbury Crossing neighborhood.
Hudson paid $3 million for that multifamily dwelling, which she purchased on Dec. 15, 2023, just two weeks after buying the properties in Dorchester.
In its listing, the property was described as a “one-of-a-kind three-family home” that features a total of 15 bedrooms and 8.5 bathrooms spread across three separate units.
When it was listed, the description noted that all three of the units were leased until August 2024, “generating a rental income of $17,675 a month.”
On all of the mortgage documents for those properties, Hudson listed a fourth dwelling—this time a single-family home—as her residence, a quaint two-bedroom cottage in Harwich, MA, which she purchased for $610,000 in October 2023.
Located on the side of a pond, the property features two bathrooms and a “small but workable” kitchen, per the listing.

Shirtless Bill Belichick seen sneaking from 24-year-old girlfriend’s home in newest dating twist
It appears there’s a new twist in this tale of the tape.
Months after Ring camera footage surfaced of a shirtless man — whom many believed to be Bill Belichick — leaving a house in the morning, the Daily Mail reported Wednesday the video blasted on social media in November 2023 was the eight-time Super Bowl winner exiting the Massachusetts residence of his 24-year-old girlfriend, former cheerleader Jordon Hudson.
The latest Belichick revelation comes days after TMZ revealed the former Patriots coach, 72, is dating Hudson, whom he met on a plane in 2021.
Belichick was said to be enthralled with the then-student-athlete’s philosophy project and even signed his autograph in her “Deductive Logic” textbook.
“Jordon, Thanks for giving me a course on logic! Safe travels!” Belichick wrote before signing his name.
TMZ obtained a photo of their first encounter Tuesday which featured the pair smiling.
Belichick’s relationship with Hudson turned romantic following his split from longtime girlfriend Linda Holliday.
Page Six reported in September 2023 that Belichick and Holliday — who had been together since 2007 — were “involved in a drawn-out, back-and-forth breakup for nearly a year.”
Belichick’s dalliances became a punchline at Tom Brady’s raunchy Netflix roast last month, with the legendary Patriots quarterback torching his former coach over the early-hours exit in the Ring video.
“Everybody asks me which ring is my favorite, I used to say ‘the next one.’ But now that I am retired, my favorite Ring is the camera that caught Coach Belichick slinking out of that poor girl’s house a few months ago. Hey, you still got it. Respect baby,” Brady, a seven-time Super Bowl champ, quipped.
Belichick and Brady, 46, won six Super Bowls during their 20 seasons together in New England.
Brady won what would be his final championship in 2021 when he was a member of the Buccaneers.
The future Hall-of-Fame quarterback retired from the NFL in 2023 after 23 seasons.
Belichick and the Patriots parted ways in January after 24 seasons.

Bill Belichick is unknowingly playing with one of his Super Bowl rings. The ring is the size of a shot glass, and each time he turns it in his hand, light dances around the room. His other hand is draped casually over the shoulder of his longtime partner, Linda Holliday, and clasps hers. They’re sitting on a casual, unfussy couch in the Belichick’s living room in ‘Sconset. The space is quaint and comfortable. An antique Wurlitzer jukebox stands quietly behind them and there’s a seascape painting hanging over the mantel. Beyond locker rooms, practice fields and stadiums, this is the inner sanctum of arguably the greatest coach in the history of sports.
“I started off in Detroit, then Denver, then the Giants, then Cleveland, then the Patriots, then the Jets, and then the Patriots [again],” Belichick says. “But at the end of every one of those years I was here.” He slaps his knee. “Nantucket has always been a constant.” Belichick first discovered the island while he was in high school in Annapolis, Maryland where his father was a football coach at the US Naval Academy. His high school friend Mark Fredland had a family home on the island and invited him to join one summer. In 1979, he and Fredland purchased this plot of land off Sankaty Road and developed it together. Fredland still lives nearby. It’s a charming property that harks back to the old Nantucket when screen doors clapped closed and unpretentiousness was a community ethos.
“This is where everybody flocks home,” says Holliday. “No matter what everybody is doing during their busy lives, Nantucket is where family comes together as a unit again.” If there was ever kryptonite to soften the steeliest coach in the game, it’s Linda Holliday. Warm and vivacious, she pairs well with Belichick — or as he put it earlier in the day, “She’s the rose next to the thorn.” The couple appear completely at ease with one another and share a playfulness and unabashed affection that belies Belichick’s stern on-field persona. Indeed, Holliday knows a side of the coach that very few do, and she smiles widely when asked what most people would be surprised to learn about him. “I’ll tell you something about Bill,” she says with a hint of Tennessee twang in her voice. “He can sing. And he can sing well. You won’t hear it. You won’t see it. But he can sing well.” A boyish grin spreads across Belichick’s face, and for an instant, one almost forgets that this is the same man who leads 350-pound behemoths into battle.
Belichick is coming off what is widely considered to be the greatest victory in Super Bowl history — perhaps the greatest comeback in all of sports. His improbable win over the Falcons — clawing back from a 28-3 deficit with less than a half to play—only further cemented his legend. If there’s ever a question of how many championships he’s won in his forty-two-year career, one only needs to find Belichick’s fishing boat—now renamed VII RINGS — bobbing in Nantucket harbor to get the official count. And yet despite being one of the winningest coaches in NFL history, Belichick has earned a reputation for not relishing his victories.
It begs the question whether he allows himself to savor victory at all? Or is his taciturn demeanor a deliberate part of his coaching style to keep his team level? “It’s definitely part of keeping level,” Belichick responds when asked these questions. “Part of my job is to tell the truth to the team, because I feel I know the truth. When we win — and we’ve won a lot fortunately — there’s a lot of accolades of how great things are. The team gets plenty of that from outside sources. I think the pendulum swings a little too far that way in general. And so I try to swing it back a little bit the other way. Now, it’s important to celebrate wins, but not for very long.”
When asked how long his team can afford to soak up a victory, Belichick says, “For the most part it’s brief because you have to move on. If you win on Sunday and you have another game on the following Sunday, you can’t hang on to [the win] for very long. I’d say less than twenty-four hours because you have a new challenge ahead.”
Instead of reveling in the touchdowns and goal-line stops, he focuses on dropped passes, missed tackles, and botched plays. “We’re going to point those things out,” he says. “We’re going to work on them. We’re not just going to be happy that things went our way. The truth is if we don’t do better than this, we’re probably not going to win too many more games.”
He continues, “Now when things go the other way. When things aren’t going well. When the pendulum is swinging down on your team and everybody is pounding on them — the fans, the media, maybe a little bit of self doubt or lack of confidence — then that’s when they need to be brought up. I try to keep it on an even keel.”
Perhaps the most extreme example of Belichick swinging the pendulum back to center came the day after his most recent Super Bowl win. “As great as today feels,” he famously told a pack of reporters, “we’re five weeks behind the other teams for the 2017 season.” Instead of basking in the afterglow of such a biblical accomplishment, Belichick already seemed to have his eyes set on the next game eight months away. Was this statement calculated or would he simply not allow himself to revel in what many considered the greatest victory of all time?
“I definitely can hang on to that game,” he says when asked these questions. “I mean I wasn’t saying [that statement] critically or with remorse or anything; that was just a point of fact. Had we been eliminated from the playoffs in the regular season like twenty of the thirty-two teams did, we would have started immediately working on the draft, free agency, going back over the previous season. When you play an additional five weeks, and then if you win the [Super Bowl]… the reality is once you pick up the pen and paper and start going to work for the next year, the other teams are six weeks ahead of you. I was just pointing that out.”
“He can separate enjoying the win, and realizing that he has to get back to work, too,” says Holliday, who has witnessed this up close during their ten-year relationship. A former boutique clothing store owner and television personality, Holliday has brought her own unique air to Patriots Nation. This Super Bowl she grabbed fashion headlines with a custom-made Swarovski crystal Patriots hoodie, complete with BELICHICK in big sparkling letters bedazzled from shoulder to shoulder. Now she has two of her own custom-engraved Super Bowl rings to match.
“I grew up in the south, so I was an SEC football girl and never paid attention to pro football,” Holliday says. “They didn’t have pro football when I was growing up in Tennessee, so Bill has brought me into that world.” Today, Holliday serves as the executive director of the Bill Belichick Foundation, an organization Belichick credits her for starting. The organization has helped change the lives of hundreds of students from Nantucket to Uganda.
“The foundation all came together around Bill’s sixtieth birthday,” says Holliday. “In lieu of birthday presents, friends gave the first donations to the foundation.” For years, Belichick awarded scholarships in honor of his father to student athletes at his alma mater Annapolis High School. Holliday saw an opportunity to expand upon this through a nonprofit that would not only continue to award scholarships to Annapolis students, but to students across the country. “Bill and I handpick every single person,” Holliday says. “It’s not something that we take lightly. We want to know who the person is on a first name basis.”
The foundation also awards grants to help programs such as The Nantucket Skating Club, which gained vital support in 2015. Beyond Nantucket, the foundation’s reach has expanded across the country and around the globe, particularly in supporting football and lacrosse programs. “We built a field in Uganda,” Belichick says. “We’re in foreign countries. We’re national and we’re local. In particular, we try to help out Boston’s underprivileged lacrosse teams.” With a faint glimmer of pride in his voice, he adds that the lacrosse team they support in Croatia recently won the European championship.
The Bill Belichick Foundation was established in memory of Belichick’s father, Steve Belichick. Steve’s parents immigrated to the United States from Croatia at the turn of the twentieth century, and he grew up in the thick of the Great Depression. Football became his saving grace, earning him a partial athletic scholarship to college and eventually a season playing with the Detroit Lions before the war. After serving in the Navy during World War II, Steve Belichick coached for a number of college teams before assuming his thirty-three-year post as coach and scout for the US Naval Academy. Bill Belichick was four years old when his father took the job, and he grew up absorbing formative lessons from his dad on and off the field.
“When I look back on it, one of the things I learned at Annapolis, when I grew up around the Navy football teams in the early sixties — Joe Bellino, Roger Staubach, Coach Wayne Hardin and some of the great teams they had — I didn’t know any differently,” he says. “I just assumed that’s what football was. Guys were very disciplined. They worked very hard. They did extra things. They were always on time, alert, ready to go, team-oriented, unselfish. I thought that’s the way it all was. I wasn’t aware of it at the time, but I can see how that molded me.”
The military mindset Belichick witnessed at the Naval Academy is now a trademark of his coaching style. Watching him stalwartly prowl the sidelines directing his players, it’s not hard to imagine him as a field general in another life. In fact, Belichick is passionate about military history, and even narrated a PBS documentary about World War II called D-Day: Over Normandy that premiered this spring. His coaching style and personal interest in military history begs the question whether the coach could ever have pictured himself as a military leader? Could Bill Belichick see himself as a general leading troops on the battle field? “I probably wouldn’t have been a general, because I wouldn’t want to be in the Army,” Belichick says, when asked this hypothetical question. “I would have wanted to be in the Navy. I’d want to be an admiral.”
“You’re my admiral,” Holliday laughs.
There’s a certain military mentality,” Belichick continues. “When you join the military and make it a career, you’re doing it to defend the country from all enemies foreign and domestic. Basically you want to fight. That’s what they’re trained to do: to fight and to win battles and not to lose them. I’m not sure that I have that type of mentality. It’s not quite the same in business or in sports. I mean, there’s certainly things that are similar, but that fighting and playing for keeps is a little bit of a different mentality. I’m not sure that’s really the way that I’m wired.”
When asked which feeling is more intense, the thrill of winning or the pain of defeat, the coach responds without hesitation: “The disappointment of losing. The lows are lower than the highs.” He contemplates it more and continues, “But when the last game turns out like it did this year, or like it turned out two years ago — or, you know, I’ve been involved with seven championship seasons — those last a little bit longer. At some point you’ve got to move on from them, but you can hang on a little bit longer.”
Here in his home in ‘Sconset, there’s an airiness to Bill Belichick that television cameras don’t capture when he’s pacing the sidelines or stonewalling reporters after the game. Sitting next to the woman he loves, still hand in hand, he’s quick to laugh. While the conversation may have begun in true Belichickian fashion, with his responses clipped and measured, there’s now an undeniable ease to his demeanor. He’s talking about Nantucket and no question seems out of bounds.
Then, this question: “Bill, you’re obviously very well compensated for what you do…” The conversation suddenly groans to a halt. The interview has just entered uncharted waters and an uncomfortable silence floods the room. Waiting for the rest of the question, Belichick stares back with a look that could stop a bullet. “…But are you paid well enough to shop at the ‘Sconset Market?”
The coach throws his head back and breaks out into a full belly laugh. Holliday joins him. “The market is great, but the prices…” he jokes, continuing to chuckle. “That place could be a study in monopolies!” Belichick clearly loves what the ‘Sconset Market represents. Like so many spots on the island, the ‘Sconset Market connects him with his past, conjuring fond memories of when his children were young and began the day by scampering up to buy warm baked goods for breakfast. “The baked goods there are pretty hard to resist,” he says, smiling, “especially their muffins or cookies.” “And the ice cream,” Holliday adds. “Nothing better than walking down there to get ice cream.”
The exchange illustrates why he and Holliday love this island so much. Belichick appears to still relish the folksy charm and simplicity that drew him here nearly forty years ago. “The island is spectacular,” he says “The people are great, fishing, bike paths, the lighthouses, the beach, the history — I mean it’s got it all.” Holliday smiles in agreement. “It’s the feeling of getting over here and having that island factor,” she says. “You’re away from everything and yet you’re still among friends.”
“You know how it is,” Belichick continues. “When you drive along the moors, you’re going to pull over for me, and I’m going to pull over for you. It’s just a question of which one of us is finally going to go first. Because you always want to be courteous and polite to the other guy.” This good will and sense of community continues to afford Belichick and Holliday an escape from the flashbulbs and microphones that define much of their year. So no matter how many more Super Bowl rings he collects, no matter how far and wide his foundation reaches, life will always return to this quiet retreat in ‘Sconset where the most enigmatic, scrutinized coach in the game can enjoy a long, much-deserved timeout.
BELICHICK FOUNDATION SCHOLARSHIPS
Since launching in 2013, the Bill Belichick Foundation has awarded $350,000 in scholarships to student athletes across the country. Here on Nantucket, past recipients have included James Aloisi, Kezia Duarte, Megan Cranston, Nathan Leibowitz, and Olivia Slade. This past May, Katie Fox, daughter of Chicken Box co-owners Rocky and Lori Fox, was awarded one of the most recent scholarships. “I was super excited,” Fox says. “A scholarship goes a long way and motivates me to work even harder and not let the Bill Belichick Foundation down.”
An exemplary student, Fox also played varsity basketball and field hockey all four years at Nantucket High School and later became captain of both teams. Despite the time required by her athletic endeavors, Fox also volunteered extensively on the island. She was an ideal candidate for the scholarship.
“Although I don’t know Bill Belichick personally, I think that he’s a great football coach, but even a better person for helping all these kids and groups with his foundation,” says Fox, who is entering her sophomore year at UMASS Amherst and is considering studying social work. “He’s truly taken the platform he was given and is now doing whatever he can to give back. After attending the ceremony, I can see what a difference it is making.”
BELICHICK FOUNDATION GRANTS
In an effort to champion communities, the Bill Belichick Foundation has awarded $385,000 in grants in the last four years. The grant program began when Linda Holliday observed the dire needs of fledgling lacrosse programs in both inner cities and rural areas of the country. “Several friends of mine were having to do bake sales to get enough money to hire a coach and buy lacrosse sticks and get uniforms,” she says. “I was thinking that there has to be better ways to raise money and awareness for youth fun in sports as well as continue education.” Enter the Bill Belichick Foundation (BBF) grant program.
Since 2013, the BBF has awarded forty-two grants, supporting everything from building a field in Uganda to outfitting a lacrosse team in Croatia. Here on the island, The Nantucket Skating Club received a grant that dramatically propelled its mission. “We’re a small organization, but we are unique in that we have a lot more expenses compared to off-island skating clubs,” says Nantucket Skating Club president, Jody Paterson. As a 100 percent volunteer nonprofit, every fundraising dollar goes to paying for ice time, coaching, and travel to off-island competitions. The grant enabled the Skating Club to not only meet its needs on the ice, but also expand its program to incorporate off-ice training and coaching year-round. “What the Bill Belichick Foundation has done for the club has been amazing,” says Paterson. “The financial support is always welcome for any type of nonprofit, but in particular the name recognition of Bill Belichick gave a huge boost to morale and raised people’s awareness of our club.”

There doesn’t seem to be any trouble in paradise.
Jordon Hudson and boyfriend Bill Belichick’s ex-girlfriend, Linda Holliday, attended the same Massachusetts fundraiser event last Saturday, which came about eight months after the two had a confrontation at a holiday party in Nantucket.
Snapshots following the party of the 24-year-old former college cheerleader and North Carolina coach indicate nothing went down, as the couple was publicly seen smiling and holding hands in Chapel Hill.
TMZ reported earlier this week that “no issues were seen by partygoers” in what was the first public run-in between the two since Holliday allegedly confronted Hudson in December.
Holliday, who split from Belichick in 2023 after the couple dated for 16 years, felt Hudson’s presence at a party headlined by her daughters was “inappropriate” and she reportedly asked a staff member to “remove Ms. Hudson from the premises,” TMZ reported in May.
Along with Holliday and two others, the staffer went up to Hudson on the dance floor and asked her whether “she thought it was a good idea to be there.”
Hudson defended herself, claiming that her friend, former Miss Massachusetts USA Melissa Sapini, felt “threatened by Ms. Holliday” because the ex-girlfriend said if “Ms. Sapini valued her current title, she should think twice about who her friends are,” according to the incident report.
Sapini was with Hudson for Saturday’s fundraiser.
Hudson and Belichick went public with their relationship more than a year ago and things haven’t quieted down since.
Questions started to rise about Hudson’s influence after a controversial CBS interview in April, in which she directed many of the questions and denied Belichick from answering others, such as how they met.
She also recently cold-called “The Sports Gossip Show” co-host Charlotte Wilder, who discusses the relationship often on the podcast and even dedicated an episode to the Miss Maine pageant, in which Hudson placed second runner-up earlier this year.
Hudson made the call to give her opinion on the episode.
All eyes are sure to stay on the couple as Belichick prepares for his first football season with the Tar Heels, with North Carolina’s season opener against TCU set for Sept. 1.

How Jordon Hudson, 24, amassed $8 million real estate portfolio within months of meeting Bill Belichick
Bill Belichick’s spry girlfriend Jordon Hudson has amassed a New England real estate portfolio worth about $8 million — all within months of the fisherman’s daughter meeting the 73-year-old ex-Patriots coach, according to property records.
Hudson, 24, bought three multi-family homes across the Boston area in December 2023 for about $7.5 million — inking millions of dollars in mortgage agreements within days, documents reviewed by Realtor.com show.
Just two months earlier, Hudson dropped $610,000 on a cottage in the scenic Cape Cod town of Harwich, which she listed as her home address on the mortgage documents.
Those hefty purchases came about 18 months after the former cheerleader and beauty pageant contestant began dating the six-time Super Bowl-winning coach.
The couple reportedly met in February 2021 when she was 20, and their relationship was first publicly revealed in June 2024 — around the time she began showing up to her cheerleading practice in a $75,000 Porsche.
Revelations about Hudson’s seven-figure real estate portfolio come after an awkward Belichick interview with CBS News left many wondering about how much control she has over the superstar coach.
Friends of Belichick previously told The Post they were “shaking their heads” after Hudson cut off an interviewer’s question about how the couple met to declare, “We’re not talking about that.”
First reported by DailyMail.com, Hudson’s real estate portfolio suggests she has managed to grow her net worth since she met Belichick.
Hudson’s properties include a $2.2 million Dorchester townhouse that was bought with a $1.2 million mortgage in December 2023. The home is split into three apartments — one four-bed currently rents for about $5,000 per month — and appears to have undergone extensive interior renovations, according to Realtor.com.
And on the very same day she signed that mortgage, Hudson took out another $1.2 million mortgage on a second Dorchester townhouse that she bought for $2.3 million in June 2023, records show.
That townhouse has also been split into three apartments, and listings show it was “renovated to the studs” before Hudson bought it.
Her third major property was purchased on Dec. 15, 2023 — just two days later — for $3 million.
Property listings describe the large multi-family house as a “one-of-a-kind” with 15 bedrooms across three units. Those apartments were earning about $17,675 in monthly income as of August 2024, listings show.
Each of those properties was bought under an LLC, with mortgage documents listing Hudson as the “borrower.”
And her Cape Cod bungalow was bought just two months earlier in October 2023. It has two bedrooms, and is located alongside a pond in the popular New England vacation community.
At the time of the purchases, Belichick was still working as head coach for the New England Patriots, where he earned about $25 million per year and over $200 million during his more than 20-year career there, according to Bloomberg.
He now earns about $10 million annually as head coach for the University of North Carolina Tar Heels football team.
Hudson was raised in Hancock, Maine, to parents who ran a fishing business that went bankrupt after their fishing grounds were closed in 2000.
Her mother eventually moved to Provincetown, on Cape Cod, where she manages a sex-toy shop and museum.
The football star and the cheerleader are said to have met on a flight from Boston to Florida — but the pair have never publicly confirmed the stories, and the subject appears to be a sore spot for them, based on her abrupt response to a question about their meet-cute from CBS host Tony Dokoupil.
But her presence during the CBS interview was far more overbearing than that clip showed, Dokoupil said, describing Hudson as “a constant presence during our interview.”
Belichick hit back at CBS and said the network produced a “false narrative” out of the interview.
“Some of the clips make it appear as though we were avoiding the question of how we met, but we have been open about the fact that Jordon and I met on a flight to Palm Beach in 2021,” he said.
And in March, Axios revealed that Belichick had requested Hudson be CC’ed on all emails with UNC’s senior associate athletic director for external affairs and strategic communications. The Athletic reported that Hudson’s email signature described her as “Chief Operating Officer of Belichick Productions.”
Belichick broke up with his longtime girlfriend Linda Holliday in September 2023. She was 60 at the time.
He and Hudson did not respond to request for comment.

argos_summary: Bill Belichick has sold his Nantucket beachfront cottage for $3.9 million as he prepares to become the head coach at UNC, ending a 24‑season tenure with the Patriots. The sale comes amid ongoing media scrutiny of his 48‑year age‑gap romance with 24‑year‑old former cheerleader Jordon Hudson, who has rapidly built an $8 million real‑estate portfolio in Massachusetts and Cape Cod. Hudson’s purchases—three multi‑family homes and a cottage—were made through LLCs and financed with large mortgages, raising questions about her influence in Belichick’s personal and professional life. The story also highlights Belichick’s extensive property holdings, his net worth of about $70 million, and the public backlash over his relationship, including mockery from former teammates and media personalities. Overall, the article paints a picture of a high‑profile coach navigating a career transition while under intense scrutiny of his personal life and Hudson’s burgeoning real‑estate empire.
